intro: Urtica involucrata, commonly known as the woolly nettle, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its hairy, stinging leaves and stems, which contain irritant chemicals called urticating hairs. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its flowers are small and greenish, arranged in clusters, and it produces seeds that are dispersed by wind. Urtica involucrata is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of soil types.
